text: is there an article out there describing the best practice as far as julia development workflow?  Is it always best to create a package and go through the package manager even if you're never planning to register the package publicly >?

elements.text: is there an article out there describing the best practice as far as julia development workflow?  Is it always best to create a package and go through the package manager even if you're never planning to register the package publicly >?

text:
The way I do it is:
• I keep my main environment almost package free, except for Revise, OhMyREPL and some debuggers.
• I have a `Julia_Projects` folder on my documents where I keep different environments. I have one, for example, with database packages that I use when I need to play with data from a database.
• After I've played in those environments (which I keep updating), I might start a new private package on `/.julia/dev` and put whatever functionality I want. Those are never registered.
• And finally, I haven't done it yet, but I probably will move some of the more "mature" private packages to a private registry. I know people use those, I haven't gone through it yet.
• And if you think a package might be useful for more people, you can still release, but most of my packages are only used by me. I've only released one publicly thus far.

I would never touch LOAD PATH.
Just activate the environment
If really need to depend on something not registered use a Manifest.toml.
But at the point I want to depend on it, I register it.
